headline: Josh Mandel 'confident' he'll win Ohio GOP Senate primary without Trump's support
author: Amy Nelson
sentences: "A lot of those Democrats have been left behind by the Democrat Party, and theyre going to be important in my base once I win this primary seat to beat Tim Ryan and the Democrats in November," Mandel said.
Ohio Senate candidate Josh Mandel is confident he will win Tuesday's Republican primary and take Democrat Sen. Tim Ryans seat in November despite an uphill battle against Trump-backed opponent J.D.
"The people like me whove lived in Ohio our entire life  except for when I was gone in the Marine Corps in Iraq  theyre going to vote for me because they know Im born and bred here," he said.
"When we win tomorrow, were going to stand up, and were going to welcome every corner of the Republican Party and every corner of the state of Ohio to join our campaign," he said.
"Rather than running the campaign through traditional Republican Party groups, weve actually run our campaign through churches," he told co-hosts Dana Perino and Bill Hemmer.
Mandel said he doesnt believe the lack of a Trump endorsement will hurt his campaign, again expressing his confidence in coming out of the primary with the win.
Mandel said on "Americas Newsroom" Monday that his campaign strategy is something no other Ohio Senate candidate has ever done, and it will take him to victory.
Mandel said Sen. Ted Cruz, who offered his endorsement, and Gen. Michael Flynn accompanied him to campaign events at churches around the state.
Mandel did not, however, secure an endorsement from former President Trump, who won Ohio in both the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections.
"Weve got this army of Christian warriors throughout the state who are going to come out in droves and propel us to victory," he said.
Mandel said he plans to work with Trump in the general election to beat Sen. Ryan and advance the America First agenda.
He said many Ohio Democrats are not liberals, and he believes they will also support his campaign.
Mandel dismissed concerns about his polling numbers being lower than J.D.
Vance, citing his numerous fights against former moderate Republican Gov.
John Kasich and his ongoing dedication to his state.
"They know Im a proven conservative fighter."
Vance, who is leading the polls.
